repnme.cdata!:
Panama - Rural Productivity and
            Consolidation of the Atlantic Mesoamerican Biological
            Corridor Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rural Productivity
            and Consolidation of the Atlantic Mesoamerican Biological
            Corridor Project is to contribute to increased income and
            employment of small-scale rural producers in Panama. The
            extension is necessary to permit the project to complete
            successfully implementation of the activities that are
            blended with component three of loan, particularly the
            monitoring and evaluation of the environmental subprojects,
            and thereby attain its Project Development Objective (PDO)
            and Global Environmental Objective (GEO). All activities to
            be financed have been agreed with the Bank. This will be the
            first extension of the project closing date. In addition,
            the reallocation will allow the Project Implementing Unit
            (PIU) to distribute the resources under category four,
            unallocated, among the other three categories. Also,
            allocation in category three for municipal pilot subprojects
            will be reduced in 33 percent in view that only one
            municipal pilot subproject out of the two pilots originally
            planned will be implemented, as agreed in the mid-term
            evaluation in June 2011, in view of the delays for
            implementation of the decentralization law. This reduction
            will have no negative impact in the achievement of the PDO
            and GEO.

display_title.display_title:
Panama - Rural Productivity and
            Consolidation of the Atlantic Mesoamerican Biological
            Corridor Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Panama - Rural Productivity and
            Consolidation of the Atlantic Mesoamerican Biological
            Corridor Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Rural
            Productivity and Consolidation of the Atlantic Mesoamerican
            Biological Corridor Project is to contribute to increased
            income and employment of small-scale rural producers in
            Panama. This restructuring paper seeks approval of the
            Executive Directors to restructure the project to trigger
            the pest management operational policy. In addition, the
            restructuring paper informs the Board that the involuntary
            resettlement policy was applied under the project and
            reflected in the grant agreement, but it was not reflected
            in the project appraisal document. No restriction of access
            to natural resources within protected areas has occurred,
            and none is expected to occur. However, in the unlikely
            event that activities under second component for the
            implementation of management plans in protected areas were
            to restrict access to natural resources, a process framework
            is in place to address this issue. The project is currently
            rated moderately satisfactory for progress towards
            achievement of the Project Development Objective (PDO) and
            Global Environmental Objective (GEO), and moderately
            unsatisfactory for overall implementation progress. In the
            first two years after effectiveness, the project suffered
            severe delays. Since mid- 2010, project performance has been
            mixed, with strong performance between mid- and end-2010.
            The most recent project delay was caused by changes in key
            leadership within the implementing agency, National
            Authority of Environment (ANAM), in early 2011. The changes
            consist of triggering the safeguard policy on pest
            management to ensure that the project has the adequate
            safeguard management framework to supervise that
            agricultural pesticides are reaching target organisms, and
            of appropriate classification consequently not posing an
            environmental threat as well as protecting human health from
            management and use of pesticides. A small use of acceptable
            pesticides was envisaged for the implementation of the subprojects.
